newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine to export 3 mln tonnes grain this year.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine to export 3 mln tonnes grain this year.

text.p: Ukraine grain exports will reach three million tonnes in 1996, deputy Prime Minister Mykhailo Zubets predicted on Thursday.
"We will export to Russia and the Baltics, and Belarus wants to buy 1.5 million tonnes," Zubets told a news conference.
Zubets said Ukraine would not import grain this year, despite a poor grain harvest of 28 million tonnes, compared to 36.5 million tonnes in 1995.

Zubets said Ukraine's winter wheat harvest had fallen to 14 million tonnes from 16.4 million tonnes in 1995. The government had predicted earlier this year a winter wheat harvest of 15 million tonnes.
"We had a hard winter last year, the likes of which we have not seen for 20 years," Zubets said. Winter wheat is Ukraine's main grain export item.
Officials blame Ukraine's overall grain harvest figure on drought which came early in the growing season.
Zubets said the harvest of spring grain was nearly complete in most areas, but rainfall in western Ukraine was delaying grain gathering there.
Zubets re-affirmed government plans to increase winter wheat sowing this year and overall grain sowing next year to increase exports.
"Ukraine is a grain nation. It should become a main exporter of grain. It was once, and it will be again," he said.
Zubets said domestic farmers would be able to supply the state with all the grain it needed.
"The government needs to buy five million tonnes to ensure people have enough to eat," he said. "We have enough grain to feed the nation." --Irene Marushko, Kiev Newsroom, +380 44 229 2264
